author: Five Binaries
title: Cardano IPFS chronicles
description: IPFS is widely used in the Cardano ecosystem. Data stored on IPFS is prone to disappear if not used and will be lost forever.

assessments.note:
Pinning IPFS files is indeed a way to keep the IPFS resource available. 

I don't judge whether keeping these resources for one more year is wanted, or if pruning is the expected behaviour. 

I'm however noting that this is a medium term solution.
The proposal is one of value to the dev community and future Cardano users. It also bolsters the IPFS ecosystem.

A must-address-now project which would make it easier for us as a community to resolve when Cardano progresses to the level where external filing systems would need to be addressed. Kudos to the team for having foresight and proposing a solution, albeit short-term.
This sounds like an important project, however it is not clear that it directly meets the fund challenge.

Reliable decentralised storage would without a doubt improve the experience of developers working on Cardano based projects. Having a place to store the files needed for their projects would eliminate a lot of time spent searching/implementing storage solution. Both users and developers on Cardano would benefit greatly from a free automatic IPFS pinning service.
The plan is a solid one. The company behind seems to be very close to the Cardano Ecosystem.

The proposer clearly presents its credentials and, taking the 'Comments' attached to this proposal, have also identified current Cardano clients and users of its temporary system (i.e. pool.pm). Their relationship with Emurgo and the Foundation indicates a solid background and proven deliverer of solutions. Providing their url and additional information on ipfs for the newbies also provides additional confidence that they've 'done this before' and can execute the plan.
The proposers are just asking for a small amount of funds to continue what they are doing, thus they should be able to deliver.

Blockfrost is already an established company in the Cardano ecosystem, as such the likelihood of the team successfully implementing the scope of this proposal is very high. The budget presented is clear and understandable. The deployment date is outlined, what success looks like is clearly described. The service already exists, the funds from Catalyst would only improve it.
Feasibility is already demonstrated from past experience. The evaluation of costs lacks details, but doesn't sound irrelevant.
There is a clear picture of the general need and usefulness of the proposal. But it is short on details.

The proposal is forthright enough about opening up its book-keeping to the community that auditing does not seem to be an arduous exercise. The team has provided enough information on background, plans and pricing to build confidence that it would address the challenge and would be of great benefit to the community, especially given how CNFTs have grown. However, it didn't receive a 5-star rating as the proposal does not provide insight on what happens after six months when the funds requested is obviously spent. How does this tie in with Cardano releases and what if there are delays in the Mainnet releases? It might be beneficial if 'what-if' scenarios are added to the proposal seeing as though this is a short-term solution. Points given for presenting server solutions spread across the globe however, the pricing presented is from a single source (currently the provider being used by the proposers themselves). There may be benefits to Catalyst if the lowest possible price is presented and/or costing from other providers for comparison with pros and cons. This would be in case an extension past six months is required by the team and any additional cost to further provide the service past six months is required. Overall, good proposal.

The project is feasible. More information should be provided on how this project meets the challenge. It seems this is targeted at the whole Cardano ecosystem, as opposed to developers. Though I can see how Dev's might not want to use IPFS on Cardano without something like this.

Verifying if the proposal achieved its deliverables would be an extremely easy thing since the scope of this proposal is the deployment of servers. My only concern with this proposal is that the company behind it already offers the service described in the proposal as a paid service for Cardano developers, with the option of a limited free plan that seems to be subsidised by the paid subscription. However no attempt is made in the proposal to clarify why and how the result of them being funded through Catalyst would differ from the free service they are already provided. Maybe it will, but the info is not in the proposal. I would suggest clarifying this aspect in the future.

solution: We have built a community service where we archive all IPFS data that appears on the Cardano blockchain for future generations.
experience: At Blockfrost.io, we do already store all the IPFS content on the Cardano blockchain. We would like to expand this community service.
